information: Multiple polls conducted in late April 2025 indicated a consistent lead for the Liberal Party in national popular vote intentions. A poll by UrduPoint (April 21) showed Liberals at 43.3% and Conservatives at 38.4%. The Globe and Mail (April 21) reported Liberals at 43% and Conservatives at 37%. An Infobae/Nanos poll (April 20) placed Liberals at 44.7% and Conservatives at 37.3%. A Liaison Strategies poll (April 17-19) found Liberals at 43% and Conservatives at 38%. The reported gap in these polls ranged from 4.9 to 7.4 percentage points.

forecast.time_left_until_outcome_known: Approximately 6 months. The 2025 Canadian federal election is scheduled for October 2025, and today is April 21, 2025.
forecast.status_quo_outcome: No - The Liberal Party wins the popular vote. Current polling from late April 2025 consistently shows the Liberal Party leading the Conservative Party by 5-7 percentage points across multiple polls.
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: The Liberal Party maintains its current polling advantage through the campaign period. The Liberals continue to lead in national polls, successfully defend their policy positions, avoid major scandals, and win the highest share of the popular vote in October 2025. The Conservative campaign fails to generate sufficient momentum to close the 5-7 point gap.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: The Conservative Party closes the current polling gap and overtakes the Liberals by election day. This could occur through effective campaigning, Liberal missteps or scandals, shifting public opinion on key issues, or the Conservatives successfully mobilizing their base while attracting swing voters. A 5-7 point swing over 6 months, while uncommon, is within the realm of historical possibility.
forecast.rationale:
The research assistant's report shows remarkably consistent polling data: four separate polls from April 17-21 all show Liberals leading Conservatives by 4.9 to 7.4 percentage points (Liberals averaging ~43.5%, Conservatives ~37.5%). This consistency across multiple pollsters strengthens confidence in the status quo outcome.

Good forecasters weight the status quo heavily because the world changes slowly most of the time. With the Liberals holding a consistent 5-7 point lead just 6 months before the election, the baseline expectation should favor a Liberal popular vote victory.

However, 6 months is a substantial period in electoral politics. This timeframe allows for: major campaign events, policy announcements, debates, economic changes, international incidents, or scandals that could shift voter preferences. Historical Canadian elections have shown meaningful poll movement over similar timeframes, though reversing a 5-7 point deficit is challenging.

My forecast is not higher (favoring Conservatives more) because: (1) multiple consistent polls show clear Liberal advantage, (2) the gap is non-trivial at 5-7 points, (3) status quo bias should be strong, (4) no evidence of recent Conservative momentum.

My forecast is not lower (favoring Conservatives less) because: (1) 6 months allows meaningful time for change, (2) polling errors occur, (3) campaigns matter and can shift opinions, (4) the gap, while substantial, is not insurmountable.

I would update toward a higher Conservative probability if: subsequent polls show the gap narrowing, major Liberal scandals emerge, economic conditions deteriorate under Liberal watch, or Conservative campaign gains traction. I would update toward a lower probability if: the Liberal lead expands, Conservatives face internal divisions, or momentum clearly favors the status quo through summer polling.
